title: Parents of Brisbane schoolgirl, 13, who killed herself reveal their regrets they couldn't help her
text:
The parents of a Year 7 schoolgirl who died by suicide two years ago have revealed their devastation at not realising the pain she was in until it was too late.

Chloe Walklate's mother Sam discovered her daughter, 13, had taken her own life after coming home early from work on September 13, 2017.

No note left by the Brisbane teenager has ever been found, but Mrs Walklate said she was 'naive' to the signs her child was suffering from mental illness.

The parents of Year 7 schoolgirl Chloe Walklate (pictured), who died by suicide two years ago, have revealed their devastation at not realising the pain she was in until it was too late

'The night before she was riding her horse and then she was on the phone to an old school friend, laughing and joking,' she said.

But looking back, the mother told The Courier-Mail she put Chloe's behavioural changes, including being unable to concentrate, down to hormones.

'She was trying to read a book and she said 'Mum, I can't read it'. I'm like 'what do you mean you can't read', but that's a sign of depression - she couldn't concentrate,' Mrs Walklate said.

And while the young girl would hide her struggle by joking around, she was unhappy at school and was skipping lessons at Windaroo Valley State High School.

The grieving mother added she has still kept Chloe's room in almost the exact same state her daughter left it - right down to a can of Coca-Cola left on the windowsill.

'Every time I look at that can of soft drink from outside the house, I still have that picture of her smiling inside my head. I don't want to move it,' Mrs Walklate said.

No note left by the Brisbane teenager has ever been found, but Mrs Walklate (pictured with her daughter) said she was 'naive' to the signs her child was suffering from mental illness

Since her daughter's tragic death, Sam and Chloe's father Kyle have become ardent campaigners for mental health awareness and suicide prevention.

In May, the Walklates arranged to take part in Tough Mudder to fundraise for the mental health charity Beyond Blue and raise awareness about youth suicide.

Last month, Sam spoke on World Suicide Prevention Day to talk about the importance of remembering those who have died by taking their own life.

The grieving mother added she has still kept Chloe's (pictured) room in almost the exact same state her daughter left it - right down to a can of Coca-Cola left on the windowsill

Chloe was named earlier this year among 11 other children who died by suicide in a video addressed to members of parliament by Gold Coast woman Ursula Wharton.

Ms Wharton, who titled the video 'Taken by suicide', lost her son Josh, 17, to the same cause of death in 2017.

She said she had sent the video to MPs but had only been met with 'cut and paste responses'.

'It's actually quite hurtful, it's taken a lot of emotional energy to do this,' she said.

Australia has one of the higher rates of child suicide in the world, and it is the country's leading cause of death among young people.
